chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of medication overuse headache
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with medication overuse headache.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage medication overuse headache?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If the person has any red flags for a serious secondary cause of headache:
    • Refer to secondary care (with urgency depending on the clinical situation).
    • For information on red flags see the section on warning features of serious causes of headache in the CKS topic Headache - assessment.
  • If clinical features are consistent with medication overuse headache (MOH):
    • Explain the diagnosis of MOH and that withdrawal of the overused drug is the mainstay of treatment.
    • Discuss with/refer to neurology if overuse involves opioids or tranquillizers, significant comorbidities are present or previous repeated withdrawal attempts have been unsuccessful in primary care – inpatient withdrawal may be required.
    • Support withdrawal of the offending medication if appropriate to do so in primary care.
      • Drugs such as triptans and simple analgesics (such as NSAIDS and paracetamol) can generally be stopped abruptly.
      • Advise the person to stop taking all overused acute headache medications for at least 1 month.
      • Warn the person that withdrawal may initially worsen symptoms and that headache improvement may not occur for weeks after discontinuation.
      • Advise the person to keep a diary recording symptoms and medication use during withdrawal and to maintain good hydration.
    • Ensure associated comorbidities such as anxiety and depression are appropriately managed.
      • For more information, see the CKS topics on Depression and Generalized anxiety disorder.
    • Provide written and oral information on MOH, pre-existing primary headache disorder(s) and prevention of relapse.
      • Education on recognition of specific headache types allows the person to use medication more appropriately. For further information, see the CKS topics on Headache - tension-type and Migraine.
    • Arrange follow up to monitor progress and support the person.
      • Review and reassess the underlying primary headache disorder 4–8 weeks after withdrawing the overused medication.
      • Original headache type (migraine or tension-type headache) is usually revealed within 2 months of withdrawal. If appropriate, the overused medications may be reintroduced after 2 months, with clear restrictions on frequency of use.
      • If relapse occurs, provide ongoing support — behavioural interventions (such as cognitive behaviour therapy and stress reduction) may help.
      • For further information, see the CKS topics on Headache - assessment, Headache - tension-type and Migraine.
  • If uncertain about diagnosis/management or first line measures in primary care fail discuss with a neurologist or GP with a special interest in headache.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of medication overuse headache (MOH) are based on the clinical guidelines Guidelines for all healthcare professionals in the diagnosis and management of migraine, tension-type, cluster and medication-overuse headache [BASH, 2010], Headaches in over 12s: diagnosis and management (updated November 2015) [NICE, 2012], The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (beta version) [IHS, 2013], and Guideline for primary care management of headache in adults [Becker, 2015]  and expert opinion in review articles [Katsarava, 2013; Saper, 2013; Da Silva, 2014; Kristoffersen, 2014b] and [Kristoffersen, 2014a].

Explain the diagnosis
  • Expert opinion in clinical guideline [NICE, 2012; IHS, 2013; Becker, 2015] and review articles [Katsarava, 2013; Saper, 2013; Kristoffersen, 2014b] is that patient education is essential in management of MOH.
    • A Norwegian prospective cohort study (n=109) found that provision of basic information on appropriate medication use led to a reduction in mean medication days from 22 days to 6 days per month. At follow up (18 months) 76% of participants no longer had MOH [Grande, 2011].
Drug withdrawal
  • Guidelines from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) and British Association for the Study of Headache (BASH) recommend that specialist referral and/or inpatient withdrawal of overused medication should be considered for people using strong opioids, with relevant comorbidities, or in whom previous repeated withdrawal attempts have been unsuccessful [BASH, 2010; NICE, 2012].
  • Withdrawal of the suspected medication(s) is the only treatment for established MOH [BASH, 2010].
    • Ergots, triptans, and simple non-opioid analgesia can be stopped abruptly.
  • Withdrawal symptoms may occur and time to recovery is variable [BASH, 2010; NICE, 2012; Becker, 2015]:
    • Abrupt withdrawal may precipitate withdrawal headache which usually lasts 2–10 days (average 3.5 days) [BASH, 2010].
    • Other withdrawal symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, hypotension, tachycardia, sleep disturbances, restlessness, anxiety and nervousness [BASH, 2010].
    • Time taken to improvement varies depending on the drug overused — triptans or ergots generally take 7-10 days and simple analgesics 2-3 weeks [BASH, 2010].
Management of co-morbidities
  • Expert opinion in clinical guidelines [Becker, 2015] and review articles [Johnson, 2013; Saper, 2013; Da Silva, 2014; Kristoffersen, 2014b] is that MOH is influenced by psychiatric co-morbidities such as anxiety and depression and for treatment to be successful these must be appropriately managed.
Follow up and support
  • Expert opinion in clinical guidelines [NICE, 2012; Becker, 2015] recommends patient follow-up and support.
  • Headache diaries recording symptoms and intake of acute and symptomatic medications are important in recognition of co-existing primary headaches and prevention and treatment of medication-overuse headache [Becker, 2015].
Referral
  • Diagnosis of MOH is presumptive — withdrawal of overused medication on some occasions may not lead to recovery. If chronic headache persists, assessment for an alternative diagnosis and specialist referral is indicated [BASH, 2010; Kristoffersen, 2014b].
